user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemGetInfo(osal_id_t sem_id, OS_mut_sem_prop_t *mut_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(mut_prop);

    memset(mut_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_mut_sem_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_mutex_table, token);

        strncpy(mut_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(mut_prop->name) - 1);
        mut_prop->creator = record->creator;

        return_code = OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl(&token, mut_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_mutex_table
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_mut_sem_prop_t *mut_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The fragments above should be investigated for possible unreachable-code issues: the pointer-check macro (OS_CHECK_POINTER) is implemented via BUGCHECK and may alter control flow (e.g. trap/terminate) such that subsequent code is not reachable when invoked with a NULL pointer; the initialization (memset) and the call to OS_ObjectIdGetById may be guarded or effectively bypassed depending on the BUGCHECK behavior and/or the implementation of OS_ObjectIdGetById (if it can never return OS_SUCCESS for some builds/configurations, the entire if-block would be unreachable). The entire if-block body is therefore included because it is conditionally executed only when OS_ObjectIdGetById returns OS_SUCCESS; if that function or the transaction/convert routines always fail or always succeed in certain builds, parts of the block may be unreachable and must be checked (including the release call). Other parts of the function (local variable declarations and the final return of return_code) are straightforward, syntactically reachable from the function entry/exit and do not themselves present obvious unreachable-code concerns, so they do not need separate investigation.
